---
title: "2023-10-05 Qubit data exploration"
author: "Dan Rice"
date: 2023-10-05
toc: true
format:
  html:
    code-fold: false
---

## Objectives

Trying to understand the Qubit output.

## Preliminary work

Ari exported the data from a recent (somewhat arbitrarily selected) run to a flash drive and put it [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Qr_XHXNTNR1z33_XhSoinrYK7o-wdVdT?usp=drive_link).

Olivia looked up the concentration of the standards and [said](https://twist.com/a/197793/ch/591292/t/5608437/c/86173146):

> The concentration of Std 1 is 0 ng/uL (TE buffer). Std 2 is 10ng/uL of rRNA (also in TE buffer).

The Assay Kit User guide is [here](https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/Qubit_RNA_HS_Assay_UG.pdf)

## Data import


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(here)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
here() starts at /Users/dan/notebook
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```{.r .cell-code}
data_dir <- here("_data", "qubit")
data <- read_csv(here(data_dir, "QubitData_10-05-2023_08-32-08.csv"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

## Concentration curves

My first guess is that the relationship between concentration and RFU should be linear.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data |>
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = `Far Red RFU`, y = `Qubit tube conc.`)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](2023-10-05-qubit_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


It is not.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit <- lm(`Qubit tube conc.` ~ `Far Red RFU`, data)
print(fit)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
lm(formula = `Qubit tube conc.` ~ `Far Red RFU`, data = data)

Coefficients:
  (Intercept)  `Far Red RFU`  
     -44.6735         0.3469  
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
print(fit$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
          1           2           3           4           5           6 
 2.81107967  5.37592119  4.04156899 -6.15737272 -6.66252111 -5.53716298 
          7           8           9          10          11          12 
 0.04367763  6.19552749  4.22782719  5.67825608 -1.77123542 -5.56212970 
         13          14 
-4.00644541  1.32300910 
```
:::
:::


To be continued...
